questions.question_text: In a Decision Tree for classification, what is a leaf node?

answers.text: A node which allows classification without errors
A node which assigns a class value only by majority of examples
A node where all the objects belong to the same class
A node which assigns a class value to the objects passing the tests on the path from the root to the node itself

questions.question_text: Which of the following types of data allows the use of the euclidean distance?

answers.text: Ordered data
Transactional data
Points in a vector space
Document representations

questions.question_text: In data preprocessing, which of the following is not an objective of the aggregation of attributes

answers.text: Reduce the number of attributes or objects
Obtain a less detailed scale
Reduce the variability of data
Obtain a more detailed description of data

questions.question_text: In order to reduce the dimensionality of a dataset, which is the advantage of Multi Dimensional Scaling (MDS), with respect to Principal Component Analysis (PCA)

answers.text: MDS can be used also with categorical data, provided that the matrix of the distance is available, while PCA is limited to vector spaces
MDS can work on any kind of data, while PCA is limited to categorical data
MDS requires less computational power
MDS can be used with categorical data after a transformation in a vector space

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a strength of the clustering algorithm DBSCAN?

answers.text: Requires to set the number of clusters as a parameter
Ability to find cluster with concavities
Ability to separate outliers from regular data
Very fast by computation

questions.question_text: After fitting DBSCAN with the default parameter values the results are: 0 clusters, 100% of noise points. Which will be your next trial?

answers.text: Increase the radius of the neighborhood
Decrease the radius of the neighborhood
Reduce the minimum number of objects in the neighborhood
Reduce the minimum number of objects in the neighborhood and the radius of the neighborhood

questions.question_text: In feature selection, what is the Principal Component Analysis?

answers.text: A mathematical technique used to find the principal attributes which determine the classification process
A heuristic technique used to find a subset of the attributes which produces the same classifier
A mathematical technique used to transform non numeric attributes into numeric attributes
A mathematical technique used to transform a set of numeric attributes into a smaller set of numeric attributes which capture most of the variability in data

questions.question_text: For the data type 'Vector space with real values', which is the best suited distance function?

answers.text: Manhattan distance
Euclidean distance
Jaccard coefficient
Cosine distance

questions.question_text: For the data type 'Vectors of terms representing documents', which is the best suited distance function?

answers.text: Manhattan distance
Euclidean distance
Jaccard coefficient
Cosine distance

questions.question_text: For the data type 'Boolean data', which is the best suited distance function?

answers.text: Manhattan distance
Euclidean distance
Jaccard coefficient
Cosine distance

questions.question_text: For the data type 'High dimensional spaces', which is the best suited distance function?

answers.text: Manhattan distance
Euclidean distance
Jaccard coefficient
Cosine distance

questions.question_text: How does pruning work when generating frequent itemsets?

answers.text: If an itemset is frequent, then none of its supersets can be frequent, therefore the frequencies of the supersets are not evaluated
If an itemset is frequent, then none of its subsets can be frequent, therefore the frequencies of the subsets are not evaluated
If an itemset is not frequent, then none of its supersets can be frequent, therefore the frequencies of the supersets are not evaluated
If an itemset is not frequent, then none of its subsets can be frequent, therefore the frequencies of the subsets are not evaluated

questions.question_text: Match the situation: 'A nominal attribute needs to be used as predicting when using the sklearn library' with the best pre-processing activity

answers.text: Rescaling
Non linear transformations
Aggregation
OneHot Encoding

questions.question_text: Match the situation: 'An attribute has a very skewed distribution (e.g. most of the values concentrated in a small range, and a very long tail of outliers)' with the best pre-processing activity

answers.text: Rescaling
Non linear transformations
Aggregation
OneHot Encoding

questions.question_text: Match the situation: 'The numeric attributes have very diverse ranges of values' with the best pre-processing activity

answers.text: Rescaling
Non linear transformations
Aggregation
OneHot Encoding

questions.question_text: Match the situation: 'A categorical attribute has a too large number of distinct values' with the best pre-processing activity

answers.text: Rescaling
Non linear transformations
Aggregation
OneHot Encoding

questions.question_text: Which is different from the others?

answers.text: Silhouette Index
Gini Index
Misclassification Error
Entropy

questions.question_text: When developing a classifier, which of the following is a symptom of overfitting?

answers.text: The error rate in the test set is much smaller than the error rate in the training set
The precision is much greater than the recall
The error rate in the test set is much greater than the error rate in the training set
The error rate in the test set is more than 30%

questions.question_text: Given the following definitions: TP = True Positives; TN = True Negatives; FP = False Positives; FN = False Negatives. Which of the formulas below computes the precision of a binary classifier

answers.text: TP / (TP + FP)
(TP + TN) / (TP + FP + TN + FN)
TN / (TN + FP)
TP / (TP + FN)

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a base hypothesis for a bayesian classifier?

answers.text: The attributes must have negative correlation
The attributes must be statistically independent inside each class
The attributes must have zero correlation
The attributes must be statistically independent

questions.question_text: How can we measure the quality of a trained regression model?

answers.text: With a formula elaborating the difference between the forecast values and the true ones
With a confusion matrix
Counting the number of values correctly forecast
With precision, recall and accuracy

questions.question_text: Which of the statements below is true? (Only one)

answers.text: K-means works well also with datasets having a very large number of attributes
K-means always stop to a configuration which gives the minimum distortion for the chosen value of the number of clusters
Sometimes k-means stops to a configuration which does not give the minimum distortion for the chosen value of the number of clusters
K-means finds the number of clusters which give the minimum distortion

questions.question_text: Which of the following is not a strength point of Dbscan with respect to K-means

answers.text: The effectiveness even if there are clusters with non-convex shape
The efficiency even in large datasets
The robustness with respect to outliers
The effectiveness, even in presence of noise

questions.question_text: What does K-means try to minimise?

answers.text: The distortion, that is the sum of the squared distances of each point with respect to the points of the other clusters
The separation, that is the sum of the squared distances of each point with respect to its centroid
The distortion, that is the sum of the squared distances of each point with respect to its centroid
The separation, that is the sum of the squared distances of each cluster centroid with respect to the global centroid of the dataset

questions.question_text: Given the following definitions: TP = True Positives; TN = True Negatives; FP = False Positives; FN = False Negatives. Which of the formulas below computes the accuracy of a binary classifier?

answers.text: TN / (TN + FP)
(TP + TN) / (TP + FP + TN + FN)
TP / (TP + FP)
TP / (TP + FN)

questions.question_text: What is the cross validation

answers.text: A technique to obtain a good estimation of the performance of a classifier when it will be used with data different from the training set
A technique to obtain a good estimation of the performance of a classifier with the training set
A technique to improve the quality of a classifier
A technique to improve the speed of a classifier

questions.question_text: Which of the statements below is true? (One or more)

answers.text: Sometimes k-means stops to a configuration which does not give the minimum distortion for the chosen value of the number of clusters
K-means is quite efficient even for large datasets
K-means is very sensitive to the initial assignment of the centers
K-mean always stops to a configuration which gives the minimum distortion for the chosen value of the number of clusters

questions.question_text: In data preprocessing, which of the operations below performs aggregation? (One or more)

answers.text: Combination of two attributes in order to obtatn a more general attribute with smaller variability
Reduction of the number of distinct values of an attribute. in order to reduce its variability
Combination of two or more datasets in Order to obtatn more Information
Reduction of the number of rows of the dataset by applying a grouping on one or more attributes and computing the measures as the results of aggregation functions

questions.question_text: In a decision tree, the number of objects in a node...

answers.text: ... is bigger than the number of objects in its ancestor
... is smaller than or equal to the number of objects in its ancestor
... is not related to the number of objects in its ancestor
... is smaller than the number of objects in its ancestor

questions.question_text: What is the meaning of the statement "the support is anti-monotone"?

answers.text: The support of an itemset is always smaller than the support of its subsets
The support of an itemset never exceeds the support if its subsets
The support of an itemsets never exceeds the support if its supersets
The support of an itemset is always smaller than the support of its supersets

questions.question_text: In a dataset with D attributes, how many subsets of attributes should be considered for feature selection according ot an exhaustive search?

answers.text: O(D2)
O(D!)
O(D)
O(2D)

questions.question_text: Which is the main reason for the MinMax scaling (also known as "rescaling") of attributes?

answers.text: Map all the numeric attributes to the same range, in order to prevent attributes with higher range from having prevalent influence
Remove abnormal values
Change the distribution of the numeric attributes, in order to obtain gaussian distributions
Map all the nominal attributes to the same range in order to prevent the values with higher frequency from having prevailing influence

questions.question_text: In a Neural Network, what is the backpropagation?

answers.text: The technique used to adjust the node weights according to the difference between the desired output and the output generated by the network
The technique used to adjust the output according to the difference between the desired weights and the actual weights
The technique used to adjust the weights limiting the probability of overfitting
The technique used to adjust the connection weights according to the difference between the desired output and the output generated by the network

questions.question_text: What is the main purpose of smoothing in Bayesian classification?

answers.text: Reduce the variability of the data
Classifying an object containing attribute values which are missing from some classes in the training set
Dealing with missing values
Classifying an object containing attribute values which are missing from some classes in the test set

questions.question_text: Why do we prune a decision tree?

answers.text: To eliminate rows of the dataset which could be influenced by random effects
To eliminate parts of the tree where the decisions could be influenced by random effects
To eliminate attributes which could be influenced by random effects
To eliminate parts of the tree where the decision could generate underfitting

questions.question_text: Which of the statements below is true? (One or more)

answers.text: Increasing the radius of the neighourhood can decrease the number of noise points
DBSCAN always stops to a configuration which gives the optimal number of clusters
DBScan can give good performance when clusters have concavities
Sometimes DBSCAN stops to a configuration which does not include any cluster

questions.question_text: Which of the following is not a property of a metric distance function

answers.text: Triangle inequality
Positive definiteness
Symmetry
Boundedness

questions.question_text: What is the coefficient of determination R2?

answers.text: Provide an index of goodness for a linear regression model
Measure the amount of error in a linear regression model
Measure the amount of error in a regression model
An index of goodness for a classification model

questions.question_text: What is the first step in agglomerative clustering?

answers.text: Cluster Assignment: Assign each data point to a cluster based on the final structure obtained from the dendrogram
Initialization: Start with each data point as a singleton cluster
Pairwise Cluster Similarity Calculation: Compute the pairwise similarity or distance between all clusters
Cutting the Dendrogram: Decide on the number of clusters by cutting the dendrogram at a certain height

questions.question_text: In data preparation which is the effect of normalisation?

answers.text: Map all the numeric attributes subtracting the respective mean and dividing by variance
Map all the numeric attributes to the same range and to have a Gaussian (or normal) distribution, in order to avoid that attributes with large ranges have more influence
Map all the numeric attributes to the same range, without altering the distribution, in order to avoid that attributes with large ranges have more influence
Map all the numeric attributes in order to have a Gaussian (or normal) distribution, in order to avoid that attributes with large ranges have more influence

questions.question_text: In which mining activity the Information Gain can be useful?

answers.text: Clustering
Discretization
Discovery of association rules
Classification

questions.question_text: (refer to the image) 40%, 20%, 50%, 100%
Which of the following statements regarding the discovery of association rules is true? (One or more)

answers.text: The confidence of a rule can be computed starting from the supports of the itemsets
The support of a rule can be computed given the confidence of the rule
The support of an itemset is anti-monotonic with respect to the composition of the itemset
The confidence of an itemset is anti-monotonic with respect to the composition of the itemset

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements is true?

answers.text: The data which are similar to the majority are never noise
Outliers can be due to noise
The noise always generate outliers
The noise can generate outliers

questions.question_text: Which is the purpose of discretisation?

answers.text: Reduce the range of values of a numeric attribute, to make all the attributes more comparable
Reduce the number of distinct values in an attribute, in order to increase the efficiency of the computations
Reduce the number of distinct values in an attribute, in order to put in evidence possible patterns and regularities
Increase the number of distinct values in an attribute, in order to put in evidence possible patterns and regularities

questions.question_text: Match the rule evaluation formulas with their names (Leverage, Lift, Confidence, Conviction)

answers.text: Leverage -> 4, Lift -> 2, Confidence -> 3, Conviction -> 1
Leverage -> 3, Lift -> 1, Confidence -> 4, Conviction -> 2
Leverage -> 1, Lift -> 2, Confidence -> 3, Conviction -> 4
Leverage -> 2, Lift -> 3, Confidence -> 4, Conviction -> 1

questions.question_text: What is the difference between classification and regression?

answers.text: Classification has a categorical target, while regression has a numeric target
Classification is a supervised activity. while regression in unsupervised
Classification can make errors, while regression is always exact
Classification can have a numeric or categorical target, while regression has always a categorical target

questions.question_text: Which of the following characteristic of data can reduce the effectiveness of K-Means?

answers.text: All the variables have the same distribution of values
Presence of values with high frequency
All the variables have the same range of values
Presence of outliers

questions.question_text: In data preprocessing, which of the following are the objectives of the aggregation of attributes?

answers.text: Obtain a more detailed description of data
Obtain a less detailed scale
Reduce the number of attributes or distinct values
Reduce the variability of data

questions.question_text: Which of the statements below about Hierarchical Agglomerative Clustering is true?

answers.text: Is very efficient also with large datasets
Is based on a well founded statistical model
Requires the definition of distance between sets of objects
Requires the definition of Inertia of clusters

questions.question_text: What are the hyperparameters of a Neural Network? (Possibly non exhaustive)

answers.text: Input layers structure, Learning rate, Activation function, Number of epochs
Hidden layers structure, Learning rate, Activation function, Number of epochs
Hidden layers structure, Output layer structure, Activation function, Number of epochs
Network structure, Learning rate, Backpropagation algorithm, Number of epochs

questions.question_text: Which is different from the others?

answers.text: Dbscan
Decision Tree
Neural Network
SVM

questions.question_text: Which is the main reason for the standardization of numeric attributes?

answers.text: Map all the numeric attributes to a new range such that the mean is zero and the variance is one
Map all the nominal attributes to the same range, in order to prevent the values with higher frequency from having prevailing influence
Change the distribution of the numeric attributes, in order to obtain gaussian distributions
Remove non-standard values

questions.question_text: Which of the following measure can be used as an alternative to the Information Gain?

answers.text: Jaccard Index
Sihlouette Index
Gini Index
Rand Index

questions.question_text: Which is different from the others?

answers.text: Decision Tree
Apriori
Expectation Maximisation
K-means

questions.question_text: How is the number of clusters determined in agglomerative clustering?

answers.text: By cutting the dendrogram at a certain height.
By assigning each data point to a cluster based on the final structure obtained from the dendrogram
By computing the pairwise similarity or distance between all clusters.
By merging the closest clusters according to the defined distance metric.

questions.question_text: Which of the following clustering methods is not based on distances between objects?

answers.text: Hierarchical Agglomerative
DBSCAN
Expectation Maximization
K-Means

questions.question_text: Which is the support of the rule A,C->B?
What is the Gini index?

answers.text: An impurity measure of a dataset alternative to the Information Gain and to the Misclassification Index
An impurity measure of a dataset alternative to overfitting and underfitting
An accuracy measure of a dataset alternative to the Information Gain and to the Misclassification Index
A measure of the entropy of a dataset

questions.question_text: When is polynomial regression appropriate?

answers.text: When it is necessary to project the data into a dimensional space
When there is more than one predicting attribute
When the target values are not linearly separable
When the relationship between the predicting variable and the target cannot be approximated as linear

questions.question_text: Which of the following characteristic of data can reduce the effectiveness of DBSCAN?

answers.text: Presence of outliers
Presence of clusters with different densities
Clusters have concavities
All the variables are the same range of values

questions.question_text: Given the two binary vectors below, which is their similarity according to the Simple Matching Coefficient?
Given the following definitions: TP = True Positives; TN = True Negatives; FP = False Positives; FN = False Negatives. Which of the formulas below computes the recall of a binary classifier?

answers.text: TP / (TP + FN)
TN / (TN + FP)
TP / (TP + FP)
(TP + TN) / (TP + FP + TN + FN)

questions.question_text: What measure is maximised by the Expectation Maximization algorithm for clustering?

answers.text: The likelihood the distributions, defined by the parameters found, given the data available
The likelihood of an example
The support of a class
The likelihood of an attribute, given the class label

questions.question_text: Which of the following is not an objective of feature selection

answers.text: Reduce the effect of noise
Avoid the curse of dimensionality
Reduce time and memory complexity of the mining algorithms
Select the features with higher range, which have more influence on the computation

questions.question_text: Which is the effect of the curse of dimensionality

answers.text: When the number of dimensions increases the computing power necessary to compute the distances becomes too high
When the number of dimensions increases the classifiers cannot be correctly tuned
When the number of dimensions increases the euclidean distance becomes less effective to discriminate between points in the space
When the number of dimensions increases the results tend to be prone to overfitting

questions.question_text: Which of the following situations could suggest the use of MinMax scaling? (also known as "rescaling')

answers.text: There are attributes with very skewed data distributions
There are numeric attributes with very diverse value ranges
There is a numeric attribute with values spread in a very large range
There are attrtbutes with a very large number of missing values

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a strength of the clustering algorithm DBSCAN?

answers.text: Ability to separate outliers from regular data
Very fast by computation
Ability to find cluster with concavities
Requires to set the number of clusters as a parameter

questions.question_text: In a decision tree, an attribute which is used only in nodes near the leaves...

answers.text: ... guarantees high increment of purity
... is irrelevant with respect to the target
... gives little insight with respect to the target
... has a high correlation with respect to the target

questions.question_text: What measure is maximised by the Expectation Maximisation algorithm for clustering?

answers.text: The likelihood of a class label, given the attributes of the example
The support of a class
The likelihood of an example
The likelihood of an attribute, given the class label

questions.question_text: Which is different from the others?

answers.text: Dbscan
K-means
Decision Tree
Expectation Maximisation

questions.question_text: When training a neural network, what is the learning rate?

answers.text: The slope of the activation function in a specific node
A multiplying factor of the correction to be applied to the connection weights
The ratio between the size of the hidden layer and the input layer of the network
The speed of convergence to a stable solution during the learning process

questions.question_text: (refer to the image) 33%, 100%, 50%, 20%
Which of the statements below best describes the strategy of Apriori in finding the frequent itemsets?

answers.text: Evaluation of the support of the itemsets in an order such that uninteresting parts of the search space are pruned as soon as possible
Evaluation of the confidence of the itemsets in an order such that uninteresting parts of the search space are pruned as soon as possible
Evaluation of the support of the itemsets in an order such that uninteresting parts of the search space are considered only at the end of the execution
Evaluation of the support of the itemsets in an order such that the interesting parts of the search space are pruned as soon as possible

questions.question_text: A Decision Tree is...

answers.text: A tree-structured plan of tests on multiple attributes to forecast the target
A tree-structured plan of tests on single attributes to obtain the maximum purity of a node
A tree-structured plan of tests on single attributes to forecast the target
A tree-structured plan of tests on single attributes to forecast the cluster

questions.question_text: What is the single linkage?

answers.text: A method to compute the separation of the objects inside a cluster
A method to compute the distance between two objects, it can be used in hierarchical clustering
A method to compute the distance between two classes, it can be used in decision trees
A method to compute the distance between two sets of items, it can be used in hierarchical clustering

questions.question_text: With reference to the total sum of squared errors and separation of a clustering scheme, which of the statements below is true?

answers.text: They are two ways to measure the same thing
They are strictly correlated, if, changing the clustering scheme, one increases, then the other does the same
It is possible to optimise them (i.e. minimise SSE and maximise SSB) separately
They are strictly correlated, if, changing the clustering scheme, one increases, then the other decres

questions.question_text: Which of the following preprocessing activities is useful to build a Naive Bayes classifier if the independence hypothesis is violated:

answers.text: Discretisation
Normalisation
Standardisation
Feature selection

questions.question_text: Given the two binary vectors below, which is their similarity according to the Jaccard Coefficient?
The Information Gain is used to

answers.text: select the attribute which maximises, for a given test set, the ability to predict the class value
select the attribute which maximises, for a given training set, the ability to predict the class value
select the class with maximum probability
select the attribute which maximises, for a given training set, the ability to predict all the other attribute values
